After talking to hundreds of small businesses in Ohio and across the country, H.R. 8265 includes simplified PPP loan forgiveness processes for loans under $2 million.

RT @MarkRuffalo Pennsylvania friends: be aware that PA uses a two-envelope mail ballot system: A completed ballot goes into a ‚Äúsecrecy envelope‚Äù that has no identifying information, and then into a larger mailing envelope that the voter signs. 1/2 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eixg0grWkAcoZ5S.jpg

1. Complete your entire ballot in blue or black ink

2. Seal ballot in the smaller secrecy envelope, THEN in larger return envelope (you need both!)

3. Complete and sign the voter declaration on the back of the larger return envelope

4. Mail or drop off your ballot

@bramcla To be fair, Homo Economicus is an imaginary creature.  If people only bought cars for economically rational reasons Ferrari wouldn't exist.  Or Lexus for that matter.  But that has just as much impact on changes in opex as capex, so the logic here still holds.

16/ (Sorry for the obscure song reference - couldn't resist.)  Point is, decarbonizing transportation requires policies to lower vehicle cost.  Decarbonizing power and industrial sectors requires policies that price GHG emissions.  /fin
15/ Such a vehicle of course doesn't exist (Damn you thermodynamics!) but I think we can stipulate it would cost more than $10,000 more than Beck's current Hyundai.

14/ If you are Homo Economicus rational and you are financing your car with a 7 year, 5% loan, you'd be willing to pay about $10,000 more for that car (since at anything above that level, your car payment increase > your fuel savings)
13/ Another way to think of this for the financially inclined.  How much more would you pay for a car that had zero fuel cost?  e.g., in the example above, how much would you pay to save $150/month?

12/ To be clear, we should - nay, MUST - put a price on GHG emissions.  The point is just that decarbonizing the transportation sector will also require complementary policies that affect the price of the vehicle.  I'm a big fan of feebates, personally: https://casten.house.gov/media/press-releases/casten-introduces-legislation-reduce-vehicle-emissions
11/ Or, in economics parlance, the GHG price set in a supply/demand balanced paradigm will never clear at a high enough price to affect transportation economics.

10/ Any price that is set at a high enough level to change the economics of the heat & power sectors & decarbonize will be too low to decarbonize transpo.   And any price high enough for transpo will be way too high for H&P.
9/ Now let's bring that back to GHG pricing.   GHG pricing, by definition is applied to the thing that emits greenhouse gases when burned - the fuel.

8/ Which, by the way, is the same impact as a 25% change in fuel economy. The obvious implication being that in the (passenger) transpo sector, the economics of vehicle ownership are dominate by vehicle cost. In the heat & power sectors, the economics are dominated by fuel cost.
7/ I'll bet that's less than your monthly car + insurance payment.  And note that if the price of gasoline moves by $1 / gallon, your differential cost is just $40/month.
6/ To put this in more personal terms: in the example above, if you average 35 mpg on your commute and get 27 mpg, you're spending $155/month on $4/gallon gas.

5/ Since your fuel use is a function of operating hours (e.g., you don't burn gasoline while your car is in the garage), that means that fuel cost is ~15x as important to the investment thesis in a power plant as it is in a vehicle, all else equal.

4/ In other words, the same technology, but in one case used for power generation and in the other for transportation.  In one mode you operate 6000 hours/yr, and in the other you operate it 6000 hours over 15 years.

3/ Now suppose you also buy a reciprocating engine that in the form of your commuter vehicle (e.g., an IC engine).  You have a 45 minute (each way) commute.  You keep it for 15 years.  That engine runs 45 minutes x 5 x 52 x 15 = 5,850 hours over the course of it's entire life.

2/ Suppose you buy a reciprocating engine to generate electricity.  You run it 5 days/week, all year long, or 5x24x52 = 6,240 hours per year.  When you make that investment, you plan on keeping it for 15 years before you have to replace it.
1/ First, stipulate that "economy wide GHG pricing" is a supply/demand-set price per ton (or any other mechanism that treats all tons of GHG pollution as economically equivalent.)

Today, there are 7,000,000 cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. We don‚Äôt know how many of these Americans will be left with permanent damage to their lungs, hearts, and other organs‚Äîaka a pre-existing condition. But we‚Äôve seen that this can happen to those with even mild symptoms. (5/7)

Perhaps the worst part of this whole charade is that this is happening against the backdrop of a pandemic that will leave millions more Americans with pre-existing conditions. (4/7)

RBG‚Äôs legal work left our country in a better place, particularly for women. I want my own daughter to grow up in the world RGB envisioned.

Many doors were closed in her face. Each time she came back, ready to knock them down. We must continue the fight in her honor.

In Califano v Goldfarb, RGB argued in favor of a widower denied survivor‚Äôs benefits because he didn‚Äôt receive half of his support from his wife. Women didn‚Äôt have the same barrier.

RGB won. In the decision, Justice Brennan Jr. cited Weinberger v Wiesenfeld--another case RGB won.

Frontiero v Richardson: RBG argued in favor of Air Force lieutenant Fronteireo, who applied for benefits for her husband and was told that he didn‚Äôt qualify -- despite being her dependent.

She won, establishing a critical legal precedent against sex discrimination.

As only 1 of 9 women in law school, she rose to the top of her class while juggling the demands of caring for an ill husband and young child.

At the ACLU, she argued before the Supreme Court--and won--5 of 6 times.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a fearless guardian of our nation‚Äôs cherished principles of justice & equality. Even in death she continues to be a trailblazer, becoming the first woman to ever lie in state. 

As we honor her today, let‚Äôs revisit some of her incredible life. ‚¨á
